* {{ja-l|鮨}}, {{ja-l|鮓}}

===Etymology===
From {{m|ja|酸し|tr=sushi||sour}}, the archaic {{lang|ja|し}} (''shi'') terminal-form conjugation of modern {{m|ja|酸い|tr=sui||sour}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref>

Originally, sushi was a form of fish that had been salted and fermented for preservation without refrigeration. The fish was sometimes packed with rice or rice mixed with vinegar in order to speed the fermentation process. In the Edo period, this was also known as ''hayazushi'' ({{ja-l|早鮨}}, {{ja-l|早鮓}}) when packed in layers, pressed, and fermented for just one night. Something similar is still prepared today as ''narezushi'' ({{ja-l|馴鮨}}, {{ja-l|熟鮨}}) that relies on fermentation with no added vinegar.

The kanji are an example of {{ja-ateji|sort=すし}}.

====Usage notes====
Sushi may be counted a number of ways:
* Using the generic {{ja-l|つ||tsu}}: {{ja-l|一つ||hitotsu}}, {{ja-l|二つ||futatsu}}
* Using the generic {{ja-l|個||ko}}: {{ja-l|[[一]][[個]]||ikko}}, {{ja-l|[[二]][[個]]||niko}}
* Using the counter {{ja-l|かん}} or {{ja-l|貫||kan}}: {{ja-l|[[一]][[貫]]||ikkan}}, {{ja-l|[[二]][[貫]]||nikan}}
Historically, {{ja-l|かん}} or {{ja-l|貫||kan}} is apparently a relatively recent innovation, appearing in the 1970s. In the [[w:Edo period|Edo period]] when modern sushi first starts to appear, and all the way through the [[w:Meiji period|Meiji]] or [[w:Taishō period|Taishō]] periods, records only show the use of the generic {{ja-l|つ||tsu}} and {{ja-l|個||ko}} counters.<ref>{{cite-book
